Advancing the design of heterogeneous catalyst: Copper-montmorillonite for regioselective alkyne hydroamination Belén Alonso Investigation Gabriel Radivoy Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Juan Mancebo-Aracil Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ Instituto de Química del Sur (INQUISUR-CONICET) – NANOSYN, Departamento de Química, Universidad Nacional del Sur (UNS), Av. Alem 1253 8000, Bahía Blanca, Buenos Aires, Argentina Instituto de Química del Sur (INQUISUR-CONICET) – NANOSYN Departamento de Química Universidad Nacional del Sur (UNS) Av. Alem 1253 Bahía Blanca Buenos Aires 8000 Argentina Instituto de Química del Sur (INQUISUR-CONICET) – NANOSYN, Departamento de Química, Universidad Nacional del Sur (UNS), Av. Alem 1253 8000, Bahía Blanca, Buenos Aires, Argentina ⁎ Corresponding author. Transition metal catalysts supported on natural materials offer promising avenues for sustainable organic synthesis. In this study, we present the synthesis, characterisation, and catalytic performance of copper nanoparticles supported on montmorillonite K10 (CuMK10) as a heterogeneous catalyst for hydroamination reactions. CuMK10, synthesised through a robust and established nanoparticle synthesis methodology, demonstrates remarkable catalytic efficiency and selectivity in the synthesis of imines via hydroamination of terminal alkynes. The catalyst exhibits exceptional regioselectivity, predominantly yielding Markovnikov products, demonstrating its potential as a versatile tool in organic synthesis. Moreover, CuMK10 shows favourable reusability, offering economic benefits and practical utility due to its ease of recovery and reuse. Comprehensive structural and mechanistic studies provide insights into the catalyst's performance, paving the way for the development of efficient and environmentally benign catalytic systems. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Montmorillonite Copper Nanoparticles Hydroamination Heterogeneous catalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The synthesis of copper nanoparticles (CuNPs) and their use as catalysts for diverse organic transformations represents a highly efficient and cost-effective strategy [1]. Copper, alongside other transition metals like Ag, Au, Pd, or Pt, for instance, displays a range of oxidation states and, when nanosized possesses unique electronic properties that make it attractive and versatile for a broad range of applications [2]. This versatility makes it particularly effective in generating new CH, CC, and C-heteroatom bonds in reactions such as the Ullmann, Sonogashira, and various types of cycloadditions, amongst others. Unlike its more expensive neighbouring transition metals, copper is abundantly available and thus more economically feasible. Furthermore, copper excels in reactions involving groups with high electron density such as alkenes, alkynes, or aromatics, also demonstrating a strong affinity for nitrogen and nitrogen-based species [3]. Given its advantageous properties, copper serves as a key element in the broader context of heterogeneous catalysis, which is increasingly recognised for its potential in industrial applications. Recent advances in heterogeneous catalysis highlight the substantial promise of this field, particularly in areas such as fine chemical synthesis. On the other hand, clays such as montmorillonite are employed as catalysts due to their unique properties like acidity, ion-exchange capacity, and high surface area. These aluminosilicate minerals, part of the phyllosilicate family, are characterized by a layered structure where an octahedral sheet of alumina is sandwiched between two tetrahedral silica sheets (Fig. 1 ) [4]. This structure contributes to their versatility in various applications, including catalysis where they are used as supports for reagents and metal nanoparticles [5]. Montmorillonite, in particular, is notable for its robust, green catalytic capabilities, especially in reactions involving nitrogen-based molecules [6]. It overcomes many of the limitations of homogeneous catalysis, such as waste generation and reagent recovery issues, by facilitating easier separation processes. The clay's ability to be functionalised with various guest molecules enhances its utility in organic synthesis. Moreover, montmorillonite clays can alter their acidic properties through simple ion-exchange processes, which is beneficial in adjusting reaction environments, paving the way for their effective integration into catalyst development strategies [7]. One of the most atom-efficient reactions for nitrogen-coupling with alkenes and alkynes is hydroamination, valuable for synthesising nitrogen-containing compounds such as amines, enamines, and imines, crucial in bulk chemicals, industrial applications and pharmaceuticals [8]. Hydroamination can be catalysed by a wide range of metals, from rare-earth metals to early- and late-transition metals, in addition to Brønsted acids and bases [8,9]. Over the years, the catalysis of this reaction has been explored from various perspectives. For instance, regarding the scope, the reaction has been carried out with alkenes with stereochemical control [10–12], with internal or terminal alkynes and in the latter case, also addressing the regioselectivity of this reaction to obtain both Markovnikov and anti-Markovnikov products [13–17]. Numerous examples demonstrate this chemical transformation using both homogeneous and heterogeneous metal catalysts [18–20]. Furthermore, hydroamination is frequently employed in the field for assessing the efficiency of various catalytic systems due to its high atom economy and the significant synthetic value of the resulting products. In this study, we report the synthesis of a novel catalyst composed of copper and copper oxide nanoparticles supported on a natural inorganic solid, montmorillonite K10 (MK10). This new catalyst, CuMK10, was prepared using a nanoparticle synthesis methodology based on the fast reduction of copper(II) chloride by lithium and a catalytic amount of an arene as electron carrier [21–25]. Subsequently, the CuMK10 catalyst was thoroughly characterised and evaluated in the synthesis of imines via hydroamination with terminal alkynes. This approach not only enhances the generation of valuable products in organic, pharmaceutical, and industrial synthesis, such as nitrogen-derived compounds, but also leverages the advantages of using a heterogeneous catalyst, such as easier work-up, the potential for reuse, and thus, economic and environmental benefits. 2 Experimental Section All solvents were previously distilled. All starting materials were of the best available grade (Merck, Fluka, Anedra, AK Scientific, Alpha Aesar) and were used without further purification unless otherwise stated. Nitric acid 65 % and hydrochloric acid 37 % used for analysis of the metal traces were purchased from Cicarelli and Anedra respectively. Column chromatography was performed with Merck silica gel 60 (0.040–0.063 mm, 240–400 mesh) and hexane/EtOAc as eluent. Reactions were monitored by thin-layer chromatography on silica gel plates (60F-254) visualised under UV light and/or using ninhydrin for staining. Mass spectra (EI) were obtained at 70 eV on an Agilent HP-7890B GCMS– instrument equipped with an Agilent 5977A selective mass detector. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ARX-300 spectrometer using CDCl3 as solvent. 2.1 Preparation of the CuMK10 catalyst Commercially available copper(II) chloride dihydrate was dehydrated upon heating in oven (150 °C, 45 min). Then anhydrous copper (II) chloride (404 mg, 3 mmol) was introduced to a suspension of lithium (63 mg, 9 mmol) and 4,4′-di-tert-butylbiphenyl (DTBB, 80 mg, 0.3 mmol) in freshly distilled dry THF (10 mL) at room temperature under a nitrogen atmosphere. The initial dark blue suspension rapidly transitioned to black, indicative of the formation of copper nanoparticles suspension. This suspension was diluted with additional dry THF (10 mL) followed by the addition of montmorillonite K10 (2.4 g). The resultant mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature, quenched with water and then filtered off. The solid was subsequently washed with EtOH (3 × 5 mL) and dried under vacuum. 2.2. Characterisation of CuMK10 catalyst TEM and STEM images, together with EDX and EELS spectra, were obtained with a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 coupled to an EDAX detector and a Quantum SE 963 Gatan Imaging Filter (GIF). The samples were prepared by casting a drop of the corresponding sample dispersion on a holey carbon and/or copper grid, and then evaporating off the solvent at room temperature. Copper content in the samples was determined by atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS) using a GBC Avanta Model B-932 atomic absorption spectrometer and by inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS), in a NexION 300X Perkin Elmer instrument. In both cases, the catalyst was dissolved by adding adequate quantities of 37 % HCl, 65 % HNO3 and 50 % HF and calibrate curves were prepared with appropriate copper standards. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Nexus FT spectrophotometer instrument in the range of 4000 to 400 cm- 1 using KBr pellets; and on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrophotometer in attenuated total reflectance mode (ATR-FTIR) with a Smart iTR (Thermo Fisher Scientific) single reflection diamond (42° angle, sampling area, 1.5 mm). Spectra were collected on a range wavelength from 4000 to 650 cm-1, 256 scans and 8 cm-1 resolution. Thermal degradation was evaluated by Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) using a thermogravimetric balance TA Instrument SDT Q600 V20.9. Samples (20,4660 mg) were heated from ca 20 to 800 °C at 10 °C/min, under nitrogen atmosphere (25 mL/min). X-ray Diffraction data were collected using a PANalytical Empyrean 3 diffractometer with a Nifiltered CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) and a PIXcel3D detector. It was operated at a voltage of 45 kV and current of 40 mA. The data were collected using a continuous scan mode with slit FDS of 1/2 and FDS IBASS of 1° Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were performed using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ surface analyser with its control and data analysis software (ASiQwin 6.0). The samples underwent thermal and vacuum pretreatment by subjecting them to 150 °C and 10–2 Torr for 12 h in a 9 mm diameter glass analysis cell. The range of N2vol data absorbed was covered in the range of 7.6 to 760 Torr (P/P0 = 10–2 to 1), and it was analysed in relation to the resulting relative pressure using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory, taking the relative pressure points according to the method of Rouquerol et al. to determine the specific surface area of mesopores [26]. 2.3 Hydroamination (HA) catalysed by CuMK10 A 50 mL Schlenk flask equipped with magnetic stir bar was loaded with the corresponding amine (0.5 mmol for the synthesis of 1a to 1t; 0.25 mmol for the synthesis of 1u1 to 1w1 ), the CuMK10 catalyst (30 mg, 1.5 mol% Cu), and the alkyne (1 mmol), in 0.8 mL of xylene. Dodecane (20 mL) as internal standard for GC–MS was also added to the reaction mixture. The Schlenk tube was sealed with a ground glass cap and heated in a silicone oil bath at 160 °C under vigorous stirring. After 12–17 h, the sealed tube was cooled to room temperature, and an aliquot was filtered off through celite in order to check the conversion of the starting amine by GC–MS. The crude reaction mixture was centrifuged for recovering the catalyst which was sequentially washed with toluene, THF and finally with EtOH (1 mL each washed) several times. Isolation of the imine products is possible after fractional distillation under reduced pressure [27]. However, in most cases, conversions into the imine products were almost quantitative, and the reduction step to the corresponding amines was carried out without further purification. 2.4 Imines hydrolysis by diluted HCl After the catalyst was recovered, the crude reaction mixture from the HA reaction was transferred to a round-bottom flask and diluted with Et2O (4 mL). Subsequently, diluted HCl (10 %, 2 mL) was added, and the mixture was vigorously stirred for 20 min. The organic layer was then separated, dried, and an aliquot was taken and prepared for GC–MS analysis. 2.5 Reduction of HA products The crude product from the HA reaction (0.5 mmol assuming quantitative yield) was diluted with 2 mL of THF. Then, 2.5 equivalents of NaBH3CN were added (95 %, 83 mg, 1.25 mmol) and stirred during 30 min. Then, a solution of p-toluenesulphonic acid (15 mol% in 2 mL of THF) was added dropwise, and stirred over 2–4 h more [28]. During this time, a small portion of bromocresol green was used as indicator, maintaining the solution in an orange-yellow colour (indicating acidic pH) [29]. After that, diluted HCl (2 %, 4 mL) was added and stirred for 1 h. Finally, the resulting solution was neutralized up to pH 7–8, and the corresponding amine was extracted with Et2O (3 × 3 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with water, then with brine and dried over Na2SO4. After filtration, volatiles were removed under vacuum. The amine product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel. 2.6 Gram-scale HA catalysed by CuMK10 A 50 mL sealed glass pressure reactor tube with a Teflon stopper, equipped with magnetic stir bar was loaded with the aniline (5 mmol, 0.46 mL), the CuMK10 catalyst (300 mg, 1.5 mol% Cu), and 1octyne (10 mmol, 1.46 mL), in 3 mL of xylene. Dodecane (0.2 mL) as internal standard for GC–MS was also added to the reaction mixture. The pressure tube was sealed with a Teflon stopper and heated in a silicone oil bath at 160 °C under vigorous stirring. After 12 h, the sealed tube was cooled to room temperature, and an aliquot was filtered off through celite in order to check the conversion of the starting amine by GC–MS. The crude reaction mixture was centrifuged for recovering the catalyst which was sequentially washed with toluene, THF and finally with EtOH (2 mL each washed) several times. Then, the crude product from the HA reaction was diluted with 20 mL of THF. Then, 2.5 equivalents of NaBH3CN were added (95 %, 830 mg, 12.5 mmol) and stirred during 30 min. Then, a solution of p-toluenesulphonic acid (15 mol% in 20 mL of THF) was added dropwise, and stirred over 2–4 h more [15]. During this time, a small portion of bromocresol green was used as indicator, maintaining the solution in an orange-yellow colour (indicating acidic pH) [16]. After that, diluted HCl (2 %, 8 mL) was added and stirred for 1 h. Finally, the resulting solution was neutralized up to pH 7–8, and the corresponding amine was extracted with Et2O (3 × 6 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with water, then with brine and dried over Na2SO4. After filtration, volatiles were removed under vacuum. The amine product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel giving 1.46 g of 2a (71 % yield). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterisation of catalyst A schematic representation of our catalyst synthesis is shown in Fig. 2 . Starting from a dehydrated copper salt, it is possible to activate and reduce it with an electron transfer agent. Initially, lithium, in the presence of an arene (4,4′-di-tert-butylbiphenyl, DTBB), generates a radical anion (Ar-.) (Fig. 2 I). The radical anion is a species that possesses an odd number of electrons, and through subsequent reduction, it forms a dianionic species with a pair of electrons in the same orbital (Ar2-). These radical anions and dianions can act as electron transfer agents and react with copper chloride to produce copper in a low oxidation state (Fig. 2 II). The radical anions of DTBB are highly potent reducing agents, with the additional advantage of being soluble in organic solvents. Specifically, DTBB promotes electron transfer over potential secondary reactions, such as reduction or homo-coupling of the arene, due to the steric hindrance provided by the two tert‑butyl groups in its structure. Finally, montmorillonite K10 is added during the formation of copper nanoparticles to facilitate their deposition and dispersion on the support (Fig. 2 III). Montmorillonite emerges as one of the most prevalent smectite clay minerals, characterised by its distinctive two-dimensional nanosheet-like structures. It comprises a central octahedral sheet (AlO6) situated between two tetrahedral sheets (SiO4), with an interlayer space capable of containing water and exchangeable cations, primarily Na+ and Ca2+, as illustrated in Fig. 1 [4,30]. Acid activated MK10 was purchased from Merck, Argentina. According to the supplier, the chemical formula of the clay is: Al2O3.4SiO2.H2O, and the surface area is 220–270 m2/g. Nitrogen physisorption isotherms, along with their analysis, for MK10 and CuMK10 are shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. S2. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption in both materials (Fig. 3a and b) reveals a Type H3 hysteresis loop shape, as classified by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) [31]. This behaviour, anticipated in montmorillonite clays, suggests the presence of plate-like or disordered layer pores, known as slit-shape pores. Such a loop demonstrates an abrupt closure around relative pressures of 0.5, a trait attributed to the tensile strength effect, a metastable phenomenon. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) mathematical model and the statistical t-Plot, used to determine the specific surface area of material and mesopores, are shown in Fig. S2 for MK10 and CuMK10. The BET model linearly fits, yielding a surface area of 246.77 m2/g for MK10 and 129.28 m2/g for CuMK10. The abscissa of the t-plot is negative, indicating no presence of micropores in the MK10 sample. However, in the CuMK10, the positive intercept value confirms the presence of micropores contributing an area of 22.76 m2/g out of the total 129.32 m2/g. These differences between the two materials are significant and demonstrate that in the process of nanoparticle formation and their deposition onto the support, it's not merely about nanoparticle adsorption, but rather involves significant physicochemical changes. This results in a nearly halved surface area and the generation of larger pores between mineral particles. We believe this could be due to copper nanoparticles partially filling voids or pores in the montmorillonite, reducing its surface area, while also altering the mineral's three-dimensional crystalline structure during the process (see Fig S1). This is also in line with the pore distribution plot (Fig. 3c and d, where Rp represents pore radius in nm). The adsorption and desorption pore size distributions are nearly identical for MK10 and CuMK10. The sharp peak in the desorption distribution is not indicative of pores of that size but rather a metastable phenomenon related to N2 evaporation. In this case, the adsorption isotherm, which better represents the equilibrium situation, should be considered. With the addition of Cu, it would intercalate within the clay plate spaces, reducing the surface area and increasing the most frequent pore radius from 3.5 nm to 4.9 nm. Additionally, the presence of Cu between the plates would generate micropores with radii smaller than 1 nm. STEM and HRTEM micrographs for MK10 are depicted in Fig. S3, while those for CuMK10 are shown in Fig. 4 and S4. Analysis of the MK10 morphology reveals a broad distribution of larger particles (ranging from approximately 200 nm to 1.5 µm) with a lamellar nature, consistent with previous literature [7,32]. Basal spacing was measured across various images, yielding values between 0.98-1.20 nm (see, for instance, Fig. S3 g and h) [33]. The STEM images for CuMK10 (Fig. S4 a-c) appear similar to those of MK10, albeit with certain regions showing high contrast, which could be attributed to the presence of copper nanoparticles, amongst other factors. Therefore, Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was performed on various regions, confirming the presence of copper on the sample with energy bands of 8.04, 8.90 keV (K lines) and 0.92 keV (L line). Subsequently, Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy (EELS) confirmed the presence of copper after background subtraction (Fig S5). On the other hand, the HRTEM images of CuMK10 (Fig. S4 d-g and Fig. 4) provide more insightful information. Nanoscale spherical copper nanoparticles are observed in different images, with an average diameter of 1.7 ± 0.6 nm, well dispersed on the support (Fig. 4a and b). Additionally, the presence of larger, unidentified particles exhibiting a crystalline pattern by HRTEM is noteworthy (Fig. 4c and S4 f-g). EDX and EELS analyses in these areas confirmed a high copper content. Furthermore, the spacing between lattice planes, was accurately measured using image analysis software, yielding a consistent value of d = 0.25 nm across different images and regions. This spacing may be attributed to copper oxide, specifically assignable to CuO with a theoretical d-spacing of 0.248 nm ( 1 ¯ 11 plane), or to Cu2O with a theoretical d-spacing of 0.249 nm (111 plane) [34]. Additionally, XRD analysis of CuMK10 (Fig. S6) revealed a prominent and sharp peak at 35.7° 2Q, which could correspond to the ( 1 ¯ 11 ) plane of CuO, which supports the identification of CuO as the predominant copper oxide phase present. This observation, along with the HRTEM findings, suggests that CuO may be a predominant copper oxide phase present. Copper oxides are expected to form, as the catalyst is synthesised under reductive conditions but stored without further precautions. Meanwhile, XRD analysis did not reveal the presence of Cu(0) nanoparticles. This absence could be attributed either to the amorphous character of the CuNPs deposited on the support or to the existence of crystal domains smaller than 10 nm. The copper content in the catalyst was 1.7 ± 0.5 wt %, as determined by AAS and ICP-MS (calibration plots are shown in Fig S7). The TGA analysis for CuMK10 (Fig. S8), exhibits a behaviour similar to that of other montmorillonite minerals, wherein there is a loss of ca. 9–11 % of the weight attributed to the release of stored water [35,36]. This loss typically occurs in two stages, with the majority occurring between 40-100 °C. Additionally, a secondary decrease is observed around 300 and 500 °C, potentially indicating the loss of structural water. The total weight loss in CuMK10 was 14.35 %. However, this analysis concludes that the catalyst remains fully functional at the temperatures employed in this study. The ATR-FTIR spectra of MK10 and CuMK10, along with the assignments to the different bands, are presented in Fig. 5 and Table 1 , respectively. Both spectra are nearly identical, exhibiting typical signals for montmorillonite K10. Three defined peaks were observed: one at 3620 cm-1, assigned to the OH stretching mode of inner hydroxyl groups, and two others at approximately 3400 and 3200 cm-1 corresponding to the OH stretching mode of water [37]. The band around 1640 cm-1 is also well characterised in both spectra, assignable to O—H bending, as well as stretching and bending bands for aluminosilicates (1100–900 cm-1), with the 1000 cm-1 band (Si—O stretch) being most intense. However, the main difference lies in the 1600-1400 cm-1 region (highlighted with a yellow dashed circle). Unlike in MK10, two bands of considerable intensity appear in CuMK10, resembling the O—H bending band at 1640 cm-1, but at 1520 and 1440 cm-1. Their assignment is not trivial, and especially the band at 1520 cm-1 is believed to be due to structural changes in MK10 during the synthesis process, hence likely representing displaced O—H bending vibrations. Conversely, the band at 1440 cm-1 is possibly attributable to the stretching vibration of nanocrystal CuO [38,39]. The aforementioned, combined with observations from XRD and HRTEM, suggests the presence of CuO nanocrystals. 3.2 Catalytic activity To evaluate the catalytic properties of CuMK10, the hydroamination reaction of aniline with 1-octyne, and with phenylacetylene, was conducted using a xylenes mixture as the solvent at 160 °C (temperature of the silicone oil bath, Table 2 ). Initially, both reactions were attempted using toluene as the solvent; however, despite observing product formation, the conversions were too low. Consequently, selecting a xylenes mixture as the solvent, and increasing the reaction temperature, led to quantitative yields in both cases. Subsequently, the catalyst's efficiency in the HA reaction was evaluated at different temperatures and with varying catalyst loadings (Fig. 6 a and 6b, respectively). Additionally, the recovery and reuse of the catalyst in multiple cycles for the formation of both products were analysed (Fig. 6c). Even after 24 h with a silicone oil bath set to 140 °C and with a catalyst loading of 3 mol%, it proved insufficient to achieve satisfactory conversions to the hydroamination product (Table 2, entries 3 and 4), with the maximum conversion achieved after approximately 14 h of reaction under these conditions (Fig. 6a, 37 % conversion to imine 1a). However, increasing the oil bath temperature to 160 °C enabled quantitative conversion after 14–16 h, with over 90 % achieved after only 7 h of reaction. Additionally, excellent regioselectivity towards the Markovnikov product was observed for both compounds, with no anti-Markovnikov adduct detected. Catalyst loading was also evaluated by analysing the conversion over time for the reaction between aniline and 1-octyne at 160 °C with stoichiometries of 0.75, 1.50, and 3.00 mol% Cu (Fig. 6b). Higher catalyst loadings were also tested, yielding similar results to those seen with a 3 mol% Cu. When a copper loading of 0.75 mol% was tested, it proved to be insufficient, with a maximum conversion of 45 % observed after 20 h of reaction. However, halving the copper loading to 1.5 mol% yielded a conversion-time profile similar to the previously tested conditions, demonstrating excellent activity and selectivity. In this case, quantitative conversions were also achieved between 14 and 16 h of reaction time, with an 80 % conversion rate after 7 h. Furthermore, the catalyst proved to be reusable over multiple cycles. This was tested following the recovery of the catalyst by centrifugation after each HA reaction cycle, followed by the appropriate washings without further treatment, as specified in the experimental section. In both cases, for the formation of adducts 1a and 1b, very good conversions were achieved, exceeding 80 % after 16 h of reaction for up to four cycles. Additionally, excellent regioselectivity towards the Markovnikov product was consistently observed after each recovery and reuse of the catalyst. To elucidate the possible decline in conversion after several catalytic cycles, IR and AAS analyses were conducted on the catalyst after the fifth cycle. The IR analysis showed no apparent poisoning by nitrogen-containing organic products, as no representative signals of these were observed. However, the AAS measurement of the catalyst after the fifth cycle showed a 17 % decrease in Cu, due to the leaching of this metal. This leaching is expected given the high temperature conditions and the presence of nitrogen compounds. The turnover number (TON) was calculated in the same manner as in previous works by our group, recalculating the average particle size to metal dispersion D, according to Scholten et al., where D is copper dispersion D = Cus/Cutotal [40,41]. A dispersion of D = 56 % was obtained, yielding a TON of 469 for the reaction of aniline with 1-octyne, and 480 for the reaction with phenylacetylene. These values are very similar to those obtained with other heterogeneous catalysts for hydroamination of aniline with 1-octyne [42]. Finally, it is important to mention that the reaction between 1-octyne and phenylacetylene with aniline was also evaluated as a blank experiment to confirm the catalysis, solely under thermal conditions, in the presence of MK10 on one hand, with CuCl2 (5 mol%) as well as with CuO (5 mol%), without observing formation of the corresponding imine in any case. 3.3 Scope of HA catalysed by CuMK10 With the optimised conditions in hand (1.5 mol%, 160 °C, 16 h), the scope and limitations of the methodology were evaluated for CuMK10 in the HA reaction of a variety of primary amines and terminal alkynes (Tables 3 and 4 ). The reaction was effective for terminal alkynes and primary amines, though secondary amines and internal alkynes were not successful. First, reactions of aniline with different alkynes were evaluated (Table 3, entries 1-6). For both deactivated alkynes, such as 1-octyne, and activated ones like phenylacetylene or methyl propiolate, conversions were quantitative towards a single Markovnikov regioisomer (entries 1–5). However, an exception to this reactivity profile was observed for the reaction between aniline and 2-ethynylpyridine, yielding a mixture of regioisomers, with the anti-Markovnikov adduct being the major product (3:1 ratio) with a total conversion of 52 %. It is possible that the presence of the pyridine moiety, which has a strong copper-complexing affinity, could be leading to a different reaction pathway. Additionally, anilines bearing different substituents in the aryl ring, were evaluated with both phenylacetylene and 1-octyne (Table 3, entries 7–16). For anilines with electron-donating groups (entries 7–9), the reaction proceeded efficiently, resulting in quantitative conversions to Markovnikov products. Similarly, anilines with electron-withdrawing groups, such as halogens (entries 11–16), achieved very good to excellent conversions, consistently producing only Markovnikov products. However, strong electron-withdrawing groups significantly impacted the reaction's effectiveness. For instance, hydroamination with 1-octyne and 3-acetylaniline resulted in a moderate conversion of 54 % to the Markovnikov product (entry 10), whereas reactions with 2-, 3-, and 4-nitroaniline, which have strong electron-withdrawing effects, showed no reaction products or conversions of less than 5 % as measured by GC–MS. Furthermore, the imine derivative synthesised starting from 1-naphthylamine and 1-octyne afforded the corresponding adduct as a single regioisomer with a 70 % conversion (entry 17). The reaction was also carried out with benzylamine and dodecylamine as aliphatic amines. In the reaction of benzylamine with 1-octyne, a single regioisomer was obtained albeit in poor conversion (26 %, entry 18). However, for dodecylamine, conversions of 60 % and 73 % were achieved for reactions with 1-octyne and phenylacetylene, respectively (entries 19 and 20). Only the Markovnikov adduct was obtained for phenylacetylene, while a 3:1 mixture of Markovnikov:anti-Markovnikov adducts was observed for the reaction with 1-octyne. Additionally, the HA reaction was also tested with 1-octyne and phenylacetylene using the diamines 2,6-toluenediamine and benzidine (Table 4). In all cases, excellent conversions were obtained, yielding exclusively the Markovnikov adduct. However, mixtures of the corresponding mono- and bis-imine products were observed, with the latter being predominant in all cases. In general, imines cannot be purified by chromatographic methods using common stationary phases such as silica gel or alumina, as they can be hydrolysed in acidic media. However, imines resulting from the HA reaction can conveniently be reduced to the corresponding amines simply in the presence of sodium cyanoborohydride (see experimental section and Fig. S9) [29]. The resulting amines themselves are of significant interest for various applications. To achieve this, several selected examples were subjected to reduction of the corresponding imines by treatment with NaBH3CN in the presence of p-toluenesulphonic acid, maintaining an acidic pH for approximately 2–4 h. The corresponding amines were subsequently purified by column chromatography, yielding moderate to good yields. Following the recommendation of one of the reviewers, and to demonstrate the applicability of this methodology on a larger scale, the hydroamination reaction between aniline and 1-octyne was conducted with a tenfold increase in quantity. This resulted in a 92 % conversion to the corresponding imine 1a as measured by GC–MS, and after reduction and purification, 1.46 gs of the amine 2a were obtained (71% yield). 3.4 Mechanism of HA catalysed by cuMK10 A general proposed mechanism for hydroamination catalysed by CuMK10 is depicted in Fig. 7 . Initially, both amine and/or alkyne activation by copper, are considered feasible for this CuMK10-catalysed hydroamination. Amine activation would result in the formation of an aminoalkenyl metal complex, which subsequently could undergo a reductive elimination process to yield the hydroamination product. However, we assume that alkyne activation could be more plausible due to copper's known capability to activate CC triple bonds by π-coordination followed by copper-Csp bond formation, especially in terminal alkynes, as we observed in previous published works of our group [43–47]. In fact phenylacetylene-d was synthesised from phenylacetylene, deuterated water, and K2CO3 as base [48], resulting in a mixture of this terminal deuterated alkyne: non-deuterated alkyne at a ratio of 83:17. The hydroamination was then carried out with CuMK10 under optimised conditions, yielding the imine 1a with a lower conversion, and no observation of the deuterated product. This could be indicative of the formation of copper acetylide as a main reaction intermediate, as proposed in Fig. 7. Additionaly, a plausible kinetic isotope effect would support the lower conversion observed and suggest the involvement of copper acetylide formation in the reaction mechanism. In accordance with this mechanistic proposal, the CH activation of the terminal alkyne may take place (Fig. 7, step I), followed by the nucleophilic attack by the amine on an intermediate with high regiochemical control, predominantly yielding the Markovnikov product (Fig. 7, step II). Subsequently, α,β-ammonioalkenyl copper intermediate would be formed, with the support playing a key role in its stabilisation, facilitated by a hydrophilic environment and the excellent acid-base properties of MK10, despite the reaction occurring in a nonpolar solvent such as xylenes. Consequently, through a 1,3-proton shift or proton transfer with the support, the enamine can be generated, rapidly tautomerising to the corresponding imine, and regenerating the catalyst (Fig. 7, steps III and IV). In the case of 2-ethynylpyridine (Table 2, entry 6), for which the hydroamination process predominantly occurs with anti-Markovnikov selectivity, we hypothesise that copper could be simultaneously coordinating with the alkyne and bonded to the N atom of the pyridine ring, thereby reducing the activation of the Csp—H bond (lower conversion) and promoting aniline addition in an anti-Markovnikov way due to steric reasons. Finally, at this stage, we do not have a clear explanation for the observed formation of the anti-Markovnikov adduct as a minor product in the reaction of dodecylamine with 1-octyne (Table 2, entry 19). However, it could be attributed, to some extent, to the higher nucleophilicity of an alkyl amine in combination with a less acidic aliphatic alkyne. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully synthesised and characterised a novel heterogeneous catalyst, CuMK10, composed of copper and copper oxide nanoparticles supported on montmorillonite K10. Our study demonstrates the effectiveness of this catalyst in promoting the hydroamination reaction of various terminal alkynes with amines, yielding valuable nitrogen-derived compounds with high regioselectivity and efficiency. The detailed characterisation of CuMK10 using techniques such as nitrogen physisorption, STEM, HRTEM, XRD, AAS, and ATR-FTIR provides insights into its structural and morphological properties, confirming the presence of well-dispersed copper nanoparticles and their interaction with the support material. Additionally, the catalytic activity tests reveal the high performance of CuMK10 in terms of conversion rates, selectivity, and recyclability, highlighting its potential for practical applications in organic synthesis. Furthermore, the proposed mechanism for the hydroamination reaction catalysed by CuMK10 sheds light on the plausible pathways involved in the activation of alkynes and amines, providing a deeper understanding of the catalytic process. These findings contribute to the broader knowledge of heterogeneous catalysis mechanisms and offer opportunities for the design and development of new catalysts with enhanced performance and versatility. Overall, the successful synthesis and characterisation of CuMK10, coupled with its excellent catalytic properties, underscore its significance as a promising catalyst for various organic transformations. The insights gained from this study pave the way for further research aimed at exploiting the potential of heterogeneous catalysts, based on abundant and low-cost metals, in the synthesis of complex organic molecules with applications in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials science. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal catalysts supported on natural materials offer promising avenues for sustainable organic synthesis. In this study, we present the synthesis, characterisation, and catalytic performance of copper nanoparticles supported on montmorillonite K10 (CuMK10) as a heterogeneous catalyst for hydroamination reactions. CuMK10, synthesised through a robust and established nanoparticle synthesis methodology, demonstrates remarkable catalytic efficiency and selectivity in the synthesis of imines via hydroamination of terminal alkynes. The catalyst exhibits exceptional regioselectivity, predominantly yielding Markovnikov products, demonstrating its potential as a versatile tool in organic synthesis. Moreover, CuMK10 shows favourable reusability, offering economic benefits and practical utility due to its ease of recovery and reuse. Comprehensive structural and mechanistic studies provide insights into the catalyst's performance, paving the way for the development of efficient and environmentally benign catalytic systems.
